django.utils.crypto

Django’s standard crypto functions and utilities.

Attributes

RANDOM_STRING_CHARS

md5

Exceptions

InvalidAlgorithm

Algorithm is not supported by hashlib.

Functions

Return the HMAC of 'value', using a key generated from key_salt and a

get_random_string(length[, allowed_chars])

Return a securely generated random string.

constant_time_compare(val1, val2)

Return True if the two strings are equal, False otherwise.

Return the hash of password using pbkdf2.

Module Contents

exception django.utils.crypto.InvalidAlgorithm[source]

Bases: ValueError

Algorithm is not supported by hashlib.

django.utils.crypto.salted_hmac(key_salt, value, secret=None, *, algorithm='sha1')[source]

Return the HMAC of ‘value’, using a key generated from key_salt and a secret (which defaults to settings.SECRET_KEY). Default algorithm is SHA1, but any algorithm name supported by hashlib can be passed.

A different key_salt should be passed in for every application of HMAC.

django.utils.crypto.RANDOM_STRING_CHARS = 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789'[source]
django.utils.crypto.get_random_string(length, allowed_chars=RANDOM_STRING_CHARS)[source]

Return a securely generated random string.

The bit length of the returned value can be calculated with the formula:

log_2(len(allowed_chars)^length)

For example, with default allowed_chars (26+26+10), this gives:

  • length: 12, bit length =~ 71 bits

  • length: 22, bit length =~ 131 bits

django.utils.crypto.constant_time_compare(val1, val2)[source]

Return True if the two strings are equal, False otherwise.

django.utils.crypto.pbkdf2(password, salt, iterations, dklen=0, digest=None)[source]

Return the hash of password using pbkdf2.
